resources.string: Please detach the sensor from the cradle as shown in the image and connect it.
Please disconnect the charging cable as shown in the image and connect the sensor.
The app requires a sensor connection
Please set permissions for snoring analysis
The measurement data is insufficient. Do you want to end the measurement?
We\'ve found your old data\nWe\'re cleaning it up\nPlease wait a moment.
Device battery is low and measurement is not possible, please charge your device
Device need to connect.\nTap the Connect button to connect to your device.
Snoring is being measured. Please exit and use
We\'ve lost connection with your breath and sensors\n\nPlease check the connection status above and try again
Another user uses the sensor and shuts it down.
Soomirang, a new version has been released!\nPlease update.
Do you want to restore recently measured data?
Do you want to log out?
Respiration is being measured\nPlease exit and try to log out again
There\'s no snoring information yet\nPlease press Start.
Place your phone as shown and keep the charger plugged in.
We don\'t have enough information from your measurement\nPlease measure again tonight
This can take a few minutes.
For tonight\'s use\nPlease remove the sticker and charge it.
This can take up to 10 minutes or more.

Your sleep breathing score is based on a comprehensive analysis of the proportion of normal breathing, no breathing signals, unstable breathing, and more, using a breath-by-breath analysis algorithm.\nNote that we cannot show you if your breathing and snoring are not measured normally during sleep!
Normal, quiet breathing that occurs between 12 and 20 times per minute.

It is a condition in which breathing is abnormally reduced or blocked during sleep, resulting in weak or no breathing signals.\n\nNo breathing signals during sleep can be caused by a number of factors, including weight gain, snoring, aging, alcohol consumption, and other conditions, and should be evaluated by a physician for accurate determination.

A typical breathing rate during sleep is between 12 and 20 breaths per minute, and breathing that is faster or slower than this is referred to as:

Fast breathing: more than 20 breaths per minute.

Slow breathing: less than 12 breaths per minute.
The time and percentage of time spent in each position during sleep.\nIf you have apnea and snoring during sleep, side sleeping may help alleviate apnea more than upright sleeping.

REM (Rapid Eye Movement): The stage of dreaming characterized by rapid eye movements and active brain activity, which accounts for about 20 to 25 percent of sleep and is characterized by increased heart rate and breathing.

During REM sleep, mental fatigue is restored, stress is relieved, and short-term memories acquired during the day are stored in long-term memory. However, it is also the stage when muscles are relaxed and abnormal breathing is most common.

Light sleep: This is the initial stage of sleep, when you are in a light sleep state and can be easily awakened.

Deep sleep: This is the stage of sleep when your body and brain are resting and is closely related to sleep quality. Body temperature is lower, muscles are relaxed, and the body's immune system and cellular repair are enhanced, contributing to improved memory and learning.
